item.description:
WHAT HAS VALUE - to you, personally?  What doesn't, so much? ...And why?  Here is help to focus on what is important to you, to release more easily the many other (probably very good) things that distract you from being your very best. 

Let's have a discussion and discovery about this.  Often when we look at something from a different point of view, we see things we did not notice before. The same is true about cluttering - be that physical or mental.

Kevin Martin, a practicing certified hypnotherapist and neurolinguistic programming (NLP) Practitioner, is back to offer more pointers and frameworks for QUICKLY (on a scale of MINUTES- NOT months or years...so, practically magic: like a "Gestalt switch") "reprogram" our lives to live beyond cluttered thinking, for more successful, satisfying living- particularly regarding finances or other considerations of special value to us. As organizer of several Boston-area NLP Meetups, Kevin originally envisioned his groups would help people learn self-help tools. He often looks for resources, tools, and groups outside the fields of hypnosis and NLP to mesh with that vision -and fortunately, our group does!

 

(If you plan to eat, please arrive by 6:30 pm to order; otherwise, by 7 pm will be fine.   There is no specified purchase minimum for refreshments, but participants are encouraged to order something to support the business, in appreciation of Management's permission to meet in their space.   Please be advised: Commercial eating establishments generally do not permit on-site consumption of refreshments brought in from elsewhere, due to liability concerns, so please be considerate.)

AGENDA (timeline may vary a little)

6:30 pm- Order dinner/refreshment if you plan to eat: $2.45 (for a soda) and upward

7:00 pm- Intro to neurolinguistic programming (NLP)

7:15 pm- Roots of clutter: Cluttered thinking

7:30 pm– NLP technique(s) described

7:45 pm - Demonstration

8:30 pm- Q&A

8:45 pm- Wrap-up

 

WHAT TO BRING: Calendar to schedule Action Items (next steps), notepad & pen or other note-taking device. Dress in layers (e.g., wear a sweater in case the restaurant is cooler than you'd prefer) and comfortably, as Kevin might have us all do NLP/EFT exercises.

 

Here is one recent "case study" I can offer in rediscovering Value that I had overlooked routinely in the seeming clutter within my home: while putting back decorative knick knacks on some kitchen corner shelves following a painter's visit last week, I found myself on autopilot returning to the shelves some liqueurs in their interesting little bottles ... when it occurred to me they'd been up there for decades and I had no plans to invite people for dinner or dessert anytime soon, so I thought to myself, why not use these now, myself- at the very least to further my decluttering objectives?  The result has been delightful:  I now drizzle fresh cut fruit with amaretto or Grand Marnier, creating luscious concoctions for evening snacks!  You can do something similar, I'm sure ... just think:  how might you achieve a simple "clutter Victory" - this very weekend - perhaps by utilizing something you've been saving for a special time or person(s) that never materialized (and very possibly won't)? (For decades I'd served guests desserts other than fruit in liqueur- so, I totally forgot I even had these ingredients on hand!)

Another thought, loosely related ... more philosophical: in society, income comes from or through at least one other person with whom we've somehow interacted, perhaps indirectly, at some point. Finance is social ... so, perhaps the "Social Growth" subject that's been at least noted and tracked (is it still?), if not graded in elementary schools, might well be relabeled to better reflect the valuable financial aspect of human interaction, too? -to expand people's awareness of the broader significance of "social growth," even at an early age...to not seem so much a "throw-away subject" as kids such as I was might otherwise consider it to be. Life can be a hard master in the subject later on, if such lessons aren't learned early...

Come join us!  (Or specify a better time and place for you to do so; we'll try to schedule another meeting soon.)  Share your ideas and achievements- let's have some **FUN** with this, Guys!!

Judy

item.why: Clutter isn't always easy to distinguish from valuables...e.g., people dear to me (also celebrities!) might have partied lots & abused substances; yet connections made at such times can reap benefits that "lone wolves" like me never realized...
